security_audit.summary: Legitimate visual QA testing tool. Uses browser automation for screenshots with filesystem write access. No malicious behavior detected. Default output path to root directory is a minor concern.

medium_findings.title: Filesystem write to configurable path
medium_findings.description: The script writes screenshots to a configurable output directory (default: /root/screenshots). This is necessary for its visual QA purpose but grants broad filesystem write capability. Code at lines 148, 185: os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True) creates directories and page.screenshot() writes image files.

low_findings.title: Default output path targets root directory
low_findings.description: The default output path is hardcoded to /root/screenshots (line 31). While configurable via --output flag, the default writes to a system directory. Best practice would be to default to a user home directory or current working directory.

content.user_title: Take screenshots and run visual QA tests
content.value_statement: Manual visual testing is slow and inconsistent across devices. This skill automates full-page screenshots with GSAP animation triggers at multiple viewport sizes, then uses Claude to analyze the results.
actual_capabilities: Scroll through pages to trigger GSAP ScrollTrigger animations before capturing
Take screenshots at 9 different viewport sizes (desktop, tablet, mobile)
Capture full-page screenshots that show all page content
Run visual QA on multiple pages in sequence
Save screenshots with timestamped filenames for comparison
Ignore HTTPS errors for testing internal staging sites
limitations: Requires Playwright and Chromium browser to be installed
Does not perform visual diffing or automated comparison
Cannot test authenticated pages without manual cookie setup
Analysis of screenshots is done separately by Claude

best_practices: Run visual QA after any CSS or template changes before deploying
Use consistent viewport sizes across tests for easy comparison
Combine with Claude analysis prompt to get detailed visual feedback
anti_patterns: Skipping mobile viewport sizes when testing responsive designs
Running tests without triggering scroll animations first
Only testing on desktop and assuming mobile works correctly

faq.question: What devices does visual QA test?
faq.answer: Tests 9 viewports: 3 desktop sizes (1920px, 1440px, 1280px), 3 tablet sizes (768px, 1024px, 744px), and 3 mobile sizes (390px, 393px, 375px).

faq.question: Is visual QA free to use?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill itself is free. You only need to install Playwright and Chromium browser dependencies locally.

faq.question: Which browsers are supported?
faq.answer: Uses Chromium headless browser via Playwright. Firefox and WebKit support can be added by modifying the script.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Screenshots are saved locally on your machine. No images are uploaded to external services. Only navigates to URLs you specify.

faq.question: How do I run visual QA?
faq.answer: Say: Run visual QA on [URL] or Take screenshots of all pages on [site]. Claude will execute the script and return results.

faq.question: Can I test local development sites?
faq.answer: Yes. Use --base-url http://localhost:3000 or your local server URL. HTTPS errors are automatically ignored.
